with the church, the second and third generation of Christians going, Hey, what does this mean about
this? And what does it mean about this? And what are we, what do we have to believe and what do we
not have to believe? And all that stuff that was already, they were already deconstructing their
faith and reconstructing it as they worked through it. Yeah. We're, we're joining a, like a, you know,
a train of several thousand and they still held fast to the core beliefs and, and stuck with that,
despite the amount of persecution they faced and those messages, the core beliefs have maintained
and they've been maintained now for a couple thousand years. If you count the Jewish teaching
four or 5,000 years, at least. So it's, it's pretty amazing to consider that. And the thing that's
helpful to understand the import. I think a lot of people don't realize the importance of early
authorship that it was written down by these people is because there's this idea that you've
got Jesus, the man, and then eventually that evolved into Christ, the God man, the myth kind of.
The myth, kind of like Santa Claus was St. Nicholas, who's a real guy. And then all the time it turned
into this guy who sees you when you're sleeping and knows when you're awake and keeps record of
all that you're good and bad deeds. And so early authorship, wait, are you saying, Oh, sorry.
You can't, you got it. Spoiler alert. Yeah. Sorry.
What's helpful. I have some additional reminders in that area that the, the gospels weren't written
way later. Yes. And one of them is they are, there's aspects of Jesus ministry that are
recorded or preserved that seem to have no real point or that seem to be not helpful.
If you're trying to get this guy to ever to believe your message, why would you make the
disciples look like idiots? Right? Which they always do. Only women were the ones who believed
at first. Yeah. There's all these things that you, you, you wouldn't include those things like
random, like cursing the fig tree. Like, right. Right. I still don't know why. What's going on
in there, especially with Mark references. It wasn't the season for figs. Like when Mark puts
that in like, wait, yeah. Why include, and that's cool. Another one. That's a big one is he, he
references that Jerusalem is going to be destroyed. Right. And so if you're trying to bolster his
credibility as this guy from God, you would say, yeah, but it's never mentioned like an ax for
example, that that actually happened. You would have, if accent, you know, had been written after,
after that. So there's, there's aspects. Even, even revelation, which may have been written
in the nineties does not directly reference, Hey, Jesus said the temple was going to fall. And it
did people. Right. Like that's not even that's, there's never rubbed in your face. Yeah. And
another thing too, if the church was inventing this Jesus to meet all of its own early needs,
he didn't talk about issues that they dealt with like circumcision. Right. Like that was a huge,
I mean, the biggest church council that they ever had was on that issue or, you know, spiritual
gifts or, right. Right. Gentile inclusion or the role of women, what foods are clean or unclean.
Like those are all big things that plague the church that Jesus didn't address. So,
or not clearly enough to go, here's the answer. So if you're trying to invent this religion where he
answers all that stuff, you would, you put those words in his mouth probably. But yeah. So there's
other aspects that I've said many times, if they were creating a religion, they blew it,
they blew it. I mean, they didn't come across looking good. Jesus doesn't even know. He has
some terrible PR moments in his ministry that you go, why did you just don't include that? Don't,
you don't have to put it all in, you know, the stuff that's hard. And yeah. And yeah, your point,
Chris is a great point that they were, if they were trying to solve their own religious issues,
again, they, they massively blew it. They should have put a lot of things in Jesus's mouth
to clear things up that he didn't say. And it has been, it created a crisis like it, that, that a
lot of them were still wrestling through today. I mean, we're still, you know, why didn't Jesus
tell us what to do with cell phones? I mean, it would have been, you know, how cool it would have
been if 2000 years ago, if Jesus had said, okay, the day is going to come when you're all carrying
around this, you know, piece of metal in your pocket that will give you all information,
including all the bad information. Here's what you should do when that happens. And we got to be like,
look at my gosh, he nailed it. Like that kind of stuff would be really good. If you're inventing it,
we're not, right? They didn't even do that for their own time period, much less now. And so I
think, yeah, I've always thought one of the things I like about Christianity is what a poor attempt
at a religion it is. Yeah, it just, and then what we tend to do as Christians is and we,
we start creating a religion. We keep trying to recreate a religion after the fact.
That's, that's tough. And you see what happens when we do anything like, okay,
we've done the research, we've done the work. We're going to go with these 66. There may be
another couple that could be included, but we're not confident. So we're going to leave them out.
There may be a one or two that we're including that I could get to her questionable,
but we've been convinced to the level of conviction that this is the, they belong in.
So we're going to make that decision final now. And here we are 1500 years later,
still defending that decision. Wow. Imagine if they had said, and then this, and then this,
and then this, and this created this massive list, how we would have to do that. So people say we
want clarity, but they, but then the minute you have any clarity, like everybody feels a fit about
it. So it's, it's a tough, it's a tough win sometimes. And we mentioned, I think in the old
Testament, how much archeology supports the old Testament, but same thing in the book of Acts and
Luke and things like that. Like, um, there's a guy named Sir William Ramsey, which was this really
famous archeologist who doubted that Luke really was the author and that it was, you know, firsthand,
but then he eventually became convinced after studying it. Like, I think he became a believer.
Well, he kind of came out later that he, after studying all this stuff, but, but archeology still
applies to the new Testament too. You want to, you want to have that be our, maybe our focus next time
is so we can wrap up this canonization conversation, new Testament, especially how we ended up with the
books we did and what are some of the controversies and, uh, you know, why they even thought this was
a good idea. And then maybe we can jump over into our, some of our favorite archaeological things.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people
find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up, trust God, search for answers.
